sen.j: 無門関（むもんかん、無門關）は、中国宋代に無門慧開によって編集された公案集である。
sen.e: Mumonkan (written as 無門関 or 無門關 in Chinese characters) is a collection of koan (questions that a master gives to a person, who seeks the secret of Zen, to avoid being deviated from the correct way) compiled by Mumon Ekai in the period of Sung in China.

Mumonkan (written as 無門関 or 無門關 in Chinese characters) is a collection of koan (questions that a master gives to a person who seeks the secret of Zen to avoid deviating from the correct way) compiled by Mumon Ekai in the Sung period in China.

Mumonkan (written as 無門関 or 無門關 in Chinese characters) is a collection of koan (questions that a master gives to a person who seeks the secret of Zen to avoid deviating from the correct way) compiled by Mumon Ekai in the Sung period in China.

sen.j: 無門関には48もの公案が無門慧開によって様々な語録から選ばれ、それぞれに頌と評唱が付けられている。
sen.e: In Mumonkan, as many as 48 pieces of koan were selected by Mumon Ekai from various sources, with sho (praising words) and annotations added to each of them.

sen.e: This is a text to be always used in Kanna Zen (koan-based Zen).

sen.j: 特に最初の「狗子仏性（趙州無字）」の公案は、「犬にも仏性はあるか」に対し、「無」と答えた、というだけの内容である。
sen.e: In particular, the first piece of koan, 狗子仏性(趙州無字), is simply as follows, literally: For the question of "Is a dog provided with bussho (the Buddhist nature)?," "None" was the answer.

sen.j: しかしながら、禅者が最初に与えられる課題であり、これを解くのに3年はかかるといわれているほどの難問である。
sen.e: However, this is the first problem given to a Zen priest, and the problem is said so difficult that it takes al least three years to solve the problem.
